awd_titl_txt: A pathway to controllable n-type doping in AlGaN alloys for high power devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract: Control of the electrical conductivity of the wide bandgap alloy AlGaN for high power applications

The proposed research will extend the applicability of wide bandgap semiconductors beyond the traditional limits by novel doping and defect control processes. This will lead to effective control of electrical conductivity in materials that were traditionally classified as insulators. Extending the current limits of doping extends the functionality of this class of materials to realize applications that otherwise would not be possible.. This research will provide for a transformative and disruptive technology for power electronics and also provide a breakthrough technology for efficient doping to realize efficient deep UV emitters for water purification. The successful demonstration of such disruptive technology would revolutionize energy switching and transmission, energy storage, and related applications in electrical motor drives and other power intensive applications within the US. As such, the White House has recognized the need to build America?s leadership in this technology as part of the manufacturing innovation institutes. In general, this research will directly lead to materials that will be used for applications that deal with the preservation and extension of natural resources by: (1) allowing for the efficient use and transmission of electrical energy, (2) availability of clean potable water through disinfection by the use of UV, and (3) the detection of pollutants and other effluents. This program will provide the opportunity to educate a Ph.D. student with support from an undergraduate student on the growth and characterization of wide bandgap materials while participating with the group?s international collaborators network.

The ultimate technical goal of this proposal is to demonstrate controllable n-doping in AlGaN over the whole compositional range and to demonstrate an AlGaN-based power Schottky diode that will exceed the performance of competing SiC-based devices. The following challenges need to be met: (1) establishment of dopant incorporation and solubility limits as well as activation energies for Si and Ge; (2) identification of compensating defects and impurities in AlGaN:Si/Ge; (3) control of the identified compensators using a supersaturation and a novel Fermi level point defect control scheme; (4) demonstration of controllable low, intermediate, and high free electron densities in AlGaN; (5) fabrication of a power Schottky diode. These challenges can be finally met based on recent advanced in AlGaN thin film growth on native substrates as well as recent results on Ge-doping of GaN. The WideBandgap Laboratory at NCSU has been in the forefront of these developments by demonstrating not only the point defect control schemes but also by demonstrating its capabilities such as the first demonstration of a deep-UV laser with observable cavity modes. All these achievements have been realized using the state-of-the-art metalorganic chemical vapor deposition facility at NCSU. Identification of compensating defects and impurities will lead to better understanding of defect complexes in AlGaN and defect formation in wide bandgap materials. Since the proposed Fermi level control scheme is independent of III-nitrides,  the demonstration of advanced point level control will promote its application in other material systems.

por.por_cntn:
Following the success of III-nitrides based optoelectronics, development in wide bandgap semiconductors for electronics has offered not only record high efficiency in terms of power density but the possibility of new device concepts. As this technology continues to mature, a new opportunity has emerged in ultrawide bandgap semiconductors that would enable revolutionary capabilities. This project helped extend the applicability of ultrawide bandgap semiconductors, such as AlGaN, by introducing novel doping and defect control processes. Thus, establishing the technology as a real and viable opportunity. The project led to the demonstration of effective control of electrical conductivity by dopingin materials that otherwise were traditionally classified as insulators, extending their functionality to realize applications that otherwise would not be possible. The performed research provides for a transformative and disruptive technology for power electronics and additionally, a breakthrough technology for doping, to realize deep UV emitters such as LEDs and lasers. The successful demonstration of such disruptive technology revolutionizes energy switching and transmission, energy storage, and related applications in electrical motor drives and other power intensive applications.

The ultimate technical goal of this program was to demonstrate controllable n-doping in AlGaN over the whole compositional range with the possibility of an AlGaN-based power Schottky diode that will ultimately exceed the performance of SiC-based devices. The following challenges needed to be met: (1) establishment of dopant incorporation and solubility limits as well as activation energies for Si and Ge; (2) identification of compensating defects and impurities in AlGaN:Si/Ge; (3) control of the identified compensators using a supersaturation and a novel Fermi level point defect control scheme; (4) demonstration of controllable low, intermediate, and high free electron densities in AlGaN; (5) fabrication of a power Schottky diode. Addressing these challenges was possible based on recent advances in AlGaN thin film growth on native substrates as well as recent results on Ge-doping of GaN. 

The main project achievements are listed: (1) demonstrated conductivity in AlGaN through doping with Ge, helping to understand the role of compensation in these types of semiconductors; (2) as progress in the fabrication of power switches, we focused on the role of the surface in determining the performance of the devices by presenting the first systematic study of using silicon nitride for surface passivation; (3) demonstrated that the state of the surface plays a significant role in the performance of these nitride devices to the point of being comparable to the role of dislocations in conductivity; (4) established the role that defects play in contacts to wide bandgap semiconductors, thus, reduction of extended defects (such as dislocations) by growing on single crystal substrates degrades the performance of ohmic contacts by reducing the possible mechanisms for current injection; (5) ohmic contacts with contact resistivity in the order of 10-5Ωcm2were achieved on high-Al content AlGaN based on Vanadium contacts; (6) state-of-the-art carrier concentration of 3x1019cm-3in Al0.65Ga0.35N films grown on AlN single crystal substrates; (7) by comparing Ge with Si we established the principles of dopant engineering where the formation of compensating defects in the form of complexes needs to be considered. 

These achievements helped to establish hypotheses that will guide further development of devices on these materials, as they refocus the current understanding of the state-of-the-art of nitrides electronics. More importantly, the idea of compensation arising from vacancy complexes with the dopant specie was established experimentally and theoretically, serving as the justification for the use of alternative n-type dopants. Although the same mechanisms are operating for compensation for n-type dopants, the differences existing between the formation of two different donor complexes (two different types of donors) could be exploited to achieved higher carrier concentrations. This is based on breakthroughs in understanding these challenges on Si-doped AlGaN on sapphire and based on DFT calculations describing the role of these complexes in AlN. This hypothesis could be tested in future extensions of this work, leading to the possible reality of doping engineering in AlGaN. Future work should focus on the ultimate technical goal of demonstrating controllable n-doping in AlGaN, by realizing a practical doping toolbox that allows for the realization of advanced device structures.

The technology developed during this project was used to implement early versions of AlGaN based Schottky diodes and helped in the development of deep UV laser diodes. Realizing high n-type conductivity and the resulting understanding of the associated point defects arising from the complex interactions with the dopants, help in realizing efficient cladding and waveguides structures within the diode laser. Reducing the unwanted compensation, not only helped increased the conductivity but also further reduce any unwanted optical absorption within the device structure. As such, efficient optically pump laser structures at 275 nm with threshold pump power below 6 kW/cm2were realized.
